description: Asalaamu Alaikum (Peace Be Upon You)! Celebrate Islamic History Month this October, by experiencing the vibrancy, diversity, and innovation of Islamic cultural heritage! Join us for a free, two day celebration of Islamic cultural heritage, featuring exhibitors, food, vendors, performances, and speakers! This year the theme of Islamic History Month is “Celebrating Muslim Women in the Arts and Sciences.”  We'll be celebrating the great contributions Islam has had to arts and culture as a whole, and also give credit to some of the most important inventions, historical and modern, that come from Islam. Explore little known facts about Islamic history and culture and discover how vast and diverse it is. Our schedule of events recognizes the past, present, and future contributions by Muslim women in the fields of art and science.Join us for ongoing activities Saturday and SundayYou must register for workshops in advance.2 to 3 p.m. Saturday and Sunday - Traditional Persian and Arabic Calligraphy with Ati Zar11:30 a.m. to 12 p.m. - Calligraphy demonstration with Ati Zar1:05 to 1:35 p.m. - Spoken word performance with Labibah Salim2:10 to 3 p.m. - Minding the Skies: A Journey Through the History of Muslim Contributions to Astronomy

eventName: Traditional Persian and Arabic Calligraphy with Ati Zar
description: Join Ati Zar for an immersive workshop at Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum. In this unique experience, participants will discover the art's history, cultural context, and the transformative power of calligraphy. Ati's workshops are not just about learning the art; they're an exploration of the beauty, heritage, and creativity that calligraphy brings to life.Whether you're an aspiring artist, a lover of culture, or simply curious about the magic of calligraphy, this workshop is your opportunity to unlock the secrets of this captivating art form. Come, join us for an inspiring journey into the world of calligraphy with Ati Zar Artisan and take home your own calligraphic creation. All supplies are provided during the workshop. Only 15 spots available per day.Register now

Meet Cambridge Career Connections online for workshops on topics related to job searching and career development.All workshops are virtual, drop-in, and no registration is required. Join the program at the scheduled time on Zoom.September 19: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.September 26: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.October 3: Interview SkillsThe Interview Skills workshop offers an overview of the various elements of the entire interview process. Looking at all stages of the interview process, participants will learn the “Do’s and Don’ts” of the interview process. After attending this interactive workshop, individuals will be more confident entering an interview, know how to make a good first impression, and have the building blocks to answer interview questions appropriately.October 10: Job Searching, Networking, and Social MediaIn the interactive Job Searching and Networking workshop, participants will explore and gain knowledge about how to access the hidden vs. open job markets. Participants will explore five topics, some of which include exploring traditional vs. non-traditional job searching and the application process.Oct 17: Employer ExpectationsIn the Employer Expectations workshop, participants will explore various “Do’s and Don’ts” on how to keep a job and what employers look for and expect of their employees. From general attitude to learning about styles of manager feedback, clients will learn tips and tricks to help them meet expectations and keep their job.October 24: Getting to know your PaycheckThe interactive Getting To Know Your Paycheck workshop offers an introduction to the tax deductions that you expect to have taken off of your employment income. Looking at the breakdown of a pay stub may be confusing and stressful, especially when starting a new job. After attending this workshop, we hope that individuals have a greater understanding of what tax deductions will be taken off of employment income, why these deductions exist, and roughly how they are calculated.October 31: Workplace WellnessBe informed on how to manage workplace stress and anxiety. Not only is it important to recognize the symptoms of workplace stress, but the steps we can take to address and learn what causes it. Learn about the tips and tricks for a healthy self-care routine and how we can work to reduce/remove the source of these stressors.November 7: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.November 14: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

Become a leader in your community and share your unique perspective.Focus on Leadership is designed to provide training for racialized women interested in becoming leaders of tomorrow. Our training will focus on how to become a board member and increase networking abilities to gain access to employment opportunities focusing on team-building, problem-solving, and decision-making. As board members, you will be able to apply these skills to bring about change in the community.The topics covered are:1. Types of Boards: Governance vs. Operations2. Board Responsibilities3. Committees and Working Groups4. What to Expect Once on a Board5. Mid-Point Review and Evaluation6. Leadership Primer / Communication7. Decision Making8. TeamworkAbout Focus For Ethnic WomenFocus For Ethnic Women supports women in the Waterloo Region by providing a nurturing, culturally-sensitive environment that builds self-esteem, social networks, employment-related skills, and connections to meaningful employment.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

LGBTQ2S+ identifying individuals are invited to explore a different creative project each month in a fun and safe space.Join us for this fun, casual program. Together we will explore a new creative project with a guest artist each month. Registration is limited to 2SLGBTQ+ identifying people in Waterloo Region. This month we are exploring creative mending with Alisa McRonald. No experience is necessary and all materials are provided. Participants can choose to bring an item of clothing to embellish and mend or practice different techniques on fabric samples provided.About the instructor:Alisa McRonald’s woven weirdos live in the ironic pop-culture paradise of a Queer GenX Feminist. Her work is a tactile fruit salad with a soupçon of the esoteric. She has exhibited and performed both nationally and internationally and her work has been featured in publications such as: The New York Times, Harper’s Bazaar Japan, Nylon Magazine and Giant Robot Magazine. She was awarded the 2020 Best of Craft and Design Award from the Toronto Outdoor Art Fair.In addition to maintaining her art practice in Guelph, Alisa also acts as a creative mentor and teacher/facilitator via various organizations including Art Not Shame. She unites her entrenchment in pop culture with her unparalleled sewing/sculpture/story-telling skills. She is inspired by other handmade items such as quilts and afghans for her, these items have a feeling of nostalgia and comfort to them. In addition, Alisa often uses recycled materials to lend to the nostalgic feel as well as fit with her philosophy of re-using what she has. https://www.alisamcronald.com/This program is offered in partnership with Spectrum, Waterloo Region’s Rainbow Community Space.AGE GROUP: |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

eventName: Gardening with Bob: Pruning Trees and Shrubs Workshop
description: Learn the principles and methods of basic tree and shrub pruning in this hands-on workshop. Under the instruction of Bob Wildfong, our Heritage Gardener, you will prune young trees, shrubs and vines. Learn how to shape and train woody plants, repair damaged branches, revitalize thin growth, and stimulate foliage, flower and fruit development.  Registration required.Presenter BiographyBob Wildfong is the Horticultural Teacher/Interpreter at the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum and Doon Heritage Village, as well as the Executive Director of Seeds of Diversity, Canada's national seed saving organization, and the chair of Pollinator Partnership Canada / Bee City Canada, a research and advocacy organization that protects pollinators and their habitats. He enjoys mixing science, history, and storytelling to draw connections between the past, present, and future as we all learn crucial lessons about the sustainability of our food system and the natural ecosystems that support it.Register today

Create a unique quilt square to become a part of the larger Grand River Quilt.There are no rules for creating a square aside from a final size of 10 x 10 inches. Any approach is welcome (sewing, painting, applique, felting etc), and we encourage experimentation and creativity. The most important thing is that each square should tell your story or depict your relationship to the river. Rather than a traditional rectangular quilt, each of your squares will be tied together to create the shape of the river and be displayed with a map of the Grand River watershed identifying where each square came from. location.name: Queen's Square - Greg Hayton Meeting Room IdeaExchange

description:
Discover the rich history of the Hespeler library and the renowned Carnegie Library initiative.What is a “Carnegie library” and why was one built in Hespeler? Join historian Dr. Matthew Griffis as he tells the story of Carnegie libraries and how they impacted the development of public libraries in Ontario in the early 20th century. Drawing on years of research, Griffis will explain why Carnegie libraries were built in some locations but not others, why some Carnegie libraries shared architectural similarities while others seemed more unique, and why some Carnegie libraries have survived over a century of service while others have been closed or demolished. The presentation will include many images of library buildings from across Canada, the United States, and the United Kingdom.About our SpeakerMatthew Griffis received his PhD in library and information science from Western University in 2013. He specialized in the study of libraries as places, particularly the origins and development of modern library building designs. For over twenty years, Griffis has maintained an interest in the history of Carnegie libraries and an enthusiasm for their preservation. He has spoken on the subject previously at academic conferences and at public libraries in Ontario and the United States.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |
Adults |EVENT TYPE: |

History |
Community |

Our Chilling Candlelit Evenings are sure to give you a thrill! Visitors will get to experience Schneider Haus in a whole new light, at night! Visitors will have the opportunity to tour through what some claim as the most haunted house in Kitchener and decide whether the ghost stories are true! You can expect to hear about chilling historic events that took place in the town of Berlin, funeral practices, charming, as well as some stories from visitors who claim to have had supernatural experiences.On October 7th! Connect with Psychic Medium Diana of Waning Moon Readings. Diana has been connected to the spirit world since she was a child, but embraced fully tapping in when she was in her 30's. Diana will be doing one card pulls for guests during our evening tours and have a variety of products for sale!On October 14th and 21st ! Connect with local spiritual medium Angelina who runs The Angelic Alchemist! Angelina will be doing one card pulls for guests during our evening tour! Afterwards shop through some of her gorgeous products!Are you brave enough to creep through Schneider Haus at night? Visits are scheduled for up to 60 minutes, the last tickets of the evening will start at 9:30 pm and end at 10:30 pm.Admission: $29 per adult plus HST, – please note advance ticket purchase is required for this event; there will be no tickets sold at the door.We know everyone will be eager to get here, but please do not show up too early for your time slot to avoid line ups. eventName: Re-Storying Our Lives With Ali Burke
description:
Guided by a registered therapist, learn to creatively express your thoughts and emotions through art journaling exercises.We make meaning of our lives through the storying of experience, at times these stories can be problem-saturated, with the problems stealing focus. Through art and writing participants will have the opportunity to explore their relationships with a 'problem' in their lives, the history of it, what supports it, and what influences it.About the instructor: Ali Burke is a Registered Social Worker and Psychotherapist with over 14 years experience, she currently has a private practice in Cambridge, Ontario.  Her work is grounded in the theories of Narrative Therapy, which sees people as having many skills, competencies, beliefs, values, commitments and abilities that will assist them to change their relationship with problems in their lives.  She integrates mindfulness, cognitive behavioural therapy, and emotion focused therapy into her work.AGE GROUP: |
Teens |

location.name: At the Johnson Centre – 31 Kribbs St
location.address: At the Johnson Centre – 31 Kribbs St

description:
Meet Cambridge Career Connections online for workshops on topics related to job searching and career development.All workshops are virtual, drop-in, and no registration is required. Join the program at the scheduled time on Zoom.September 19: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.September 26: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.October 3: Interview SkillsThe Interview Skills workshop offers an overview of the various elements of the entire interview process. Looking at all stages of the interview process, participants will learn the “Do’s and Don’ts” of the interview process. After attending this interactive workshop, individuals will be more confident entering an interview, know how to make a good first impression, and have the building blocks to answer interview questions appropriately.October 10: Job Searching, Networking, and Social MediaIn the interactive Job Searching and Networking workshop, participants will explore and gain knowledge about how to access the hidden vs. open job markets. Participants will explore five topics, some of which include exploring traditional vs. non-traditional job searching and the application process.Oct 17: Employer ExpectationsIn the Employer Expectations workshop, participants will explore various “Do’s and Don’ts” on how to keep a job and what employers look for and expect of their employees. From general attitude to learning about styles of manager feedback, clients will learn tips and tricks to help them meet expectations and keep their job.October 24: Getting to know your PaycheckThe interactive Getting To Know Your Paycheck workshop offers an introduction to the tax deductions that you expect to have taken off of your employment income. Looking at the breakdown of a pay stub may be confusing and stressful, especially when starting a new job. After attending this workshop, we hope that individuals have a greater understanding of what tax deductions will be taken off of employment income, why these deductions exist, and roughly how they are calculated.October 31: Workplace WellnessBe informed on how to manage workplace stress and anxiety. Not only is it important to recognize the symptoms of workplace stress, but the steps we can take to address and learn what causes it. Learn about the tips and tricks for a healthy self-care routine and how we can work to reduce/remove the source of these stressors.November 7: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.November 14: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

Become a leader in your community and share your unique perspective.Focus on Leadership is designed to provide training for racialized women interested in becoming leaders of tomorrow. Our training will focus on how to become a board member and increase networking abilities to gain access to employment opportunities focusing on team-building, problem-solving, and decision-making. As board members, you will be able to apply these skills to bring about change in the community.The topics covered are:1. Types of Boards: Governance vs. Operations2. Board Responsibilities3. Committees and Working Groups4. What to Expect Once on a Board5. Mid-Point Review and Evaluation6. Leadership Primer / Communication7. Decision Making8. TeamworkAbout Focus For Ethnic WomenFocus For Ethnic Women supports women in the Waterloo Region by providing a nurturing, culturally-sensitive environment that builds self-esteem, social networks, employment-related skills, and connections to meaningful employment.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

eventName: Get Ready to Write Your Novel
description:
Get inspired for NaNoWriMo with a writing workshop hosted by bestselling author Margaret DeRosia.Do you want to write a novel but have no idea how to start? Feel overwhelmed because you’re sure a novel must take forever—spare time you just don’t have?November is National Novel Writing Month (NaNoWriMo) — a fun opportunity to dive in, face your fears, kickstart your writing, and realize you can tell your own story!In this workshop, learn from author Margaret DeRosia what NaNoWriMo is all about and what really goes into writing a novel. We’ll review some of NaNoWriMo's free resources, and talk about how to get started—and keep going, even if your days feel too packed to spend any time writing. We’ll discuss books you’ve loved to read, the kinds of books you'd like to write, and do some fun interactive tools together to get our creative juices flowing. By the time we finish, you’ll be ready to hit the ground running on November 1st!Author and event host Margaret DeRosia with her debut novel Eight Strings:Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

eventName: SOLD OUT “Dark Side of Galt” Walking Tours - Fall Series
description: Put on your comfy walking shoes and join us as we take a summer stroll through the past, exploring stories of disasters, hauntings and other unsavoury events that make up part of Galt's dark history.Please note: Tours begin at 6:30pm and 7:00pm sharp and run for approximately 90-minutes, departing from, and finishing up at McDougall Cottage.The tours may include hills, stairs and uneven terrain. Participants should dress for the weather. Phones are recommended, but not required, to access photos of the sites we are visiting. No washroom facilities available during tour.Ages 14 + only.Pre-registration is required and space is limited, so register early!Capacity is limited to 15 participants per walk. This event is non-refundable.Cost: $15 per person, plus HST. Additional Eventbrite fees may apply. Museum Members receive a 10% discount.

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

eventName: Dog Day at Doon - Halloween Pawty
description: Hey Dog Lovers! Halloween is all about tricks, treats and costumes, of course.We know how much you love to dress up and we know some of your furry friends do too! There’s really not much more entertaining than a pooch strutting about in a costume they love!Get your canine companions all gussied up in their best Halloween garb and break free from your ordinary neighbourhood dog walks!  Plan to join us for a fun Halloween Pawty stroll through Doon Heritage Village.  You and your furry friends will enjoy limited access to our living history village for this special, safe doggie event and all pampered pooches will receive a wee pup-friendly Halloween treat.The Village will be decorated in a fun, spooky Halloween theme and everyone will enjoy the breathtaking views and historic rural buildings which are the perfect backdrop for your photogenic four-legged friends.Please note pets will not be allowed to enter the village historic buildings or museum galleries.  All dogs must remained leashed and pet owners must pick up after their pet(s).No commercial photography permitted. No business, including professional dog trainers, may use the event to conduct their business.  Aggressive dogs are not allowed. If a dog starts acting aggressively, it must be removed from the event immediately. If a dog digs a hole, it is the responsibility of the owner to fill it before departing from the event.Included with regular admission however tickets are available for presale

eventName: Samhain (a.k.a. Halloween) Tea by the Grand at McDougall Cottage
description: Halloween enthusiasts, of all ages, are invited to don their favourite costumes and join us at McDougall Cottage for a fun-filled, spook-tacular tea to celebrate the coming of Samhain (a.k.a. Halloween).We’ll be having some of our favourite tea treats alongside goodies with a special Halloween twist (the term “finger sandwiches” takes on a whole new meaning). Plan to join us, if you dare.Costumes are encouraged, but not required.Reservations are required and space is limited, so reserve your spot now!Please note:Children under the age of three do not require a ticket, however please let us know if they are attending as it impacts our seating arrangements.

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Idea Exchange, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Idea Exchange, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information Sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Idea Exchange·  LSP staff provide orientation to Library Services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in person on select daysContact InformationSozda Hasan (she/her), LSP Settlement WorkerLanguages Spoken: Arabic, KurdishPhone: 226-972-8723Email: sozda.hasan@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Sozda before your visit.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

Meet Cambridge Career Connections online for workshops on topics related to job searching and career development.All workshops are virtual, drop-in, and no registration is required. Join the program at the scheduled time on Zoom.September 19: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.September 26: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.October 3: Interview SkillsThe Interview Skills workshop offers an overview of the various elements of the entire interview process. Looking at all stages of the interview process, participants will learn the “Do’s and Don’ts” of the interview process. After attending this interactive workshop, individuals will be more confident entering an interview, know how to make a good first impression, and have the building blocks to answer interview questions appropriately.October 10: Job Searching, Networking, and Social MediaIn the interactive Job Searching and Networking workshop, participants will explore and gain knowledge about how to access the hidden vs. open job markets. Participants will explore five topics, some of which include exploring traditional vs. non-traditional job searching and the application process.Oct 17: Employer ExpectationsIn the Employer Expectations workshop, participants will explore various “Do’s and Don’ts” on how to keep a job and what employers look for and expect of their employees. From general attitude to learning about styles of manager feedback, clients will learn tips and tricks to help them meet expectations and keep their job.October 24: Getting to know your PaycheckThe interactive Getting To Know Your Paycheck workshop offers an introduction to the tax deductions that you expect to have taken off of your employment income. Looking at the breakdown of a pay stub may be confusing and stressful, especially when starting a new job. After attending this workshop, we hope that individuals have a greater understanding of what tax deductions will be taken off of employment income, why these deductions exist, and roughly how they are calculated.October 31: Workplace WellnessBe informed on how to manage workplace stress and anxiety. Not only is it important to recognize the symptoms of workplace stress, but the steps we can take to address and learn what causes it. Learn about the tips and tricks for a healthy self-care routine and how we can work to reduce/remove the source of these stressors.November 7: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.November 14: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

Become a leader in your community and share your unique perspective.Focus on Leadership is designed to provide training for racialized women interested in becoming leaders of tomorrow. Our training will focus on how to become a board member and increase networking abilities to gain access to employment opportunities focusing on team-building, problem-solving, and decision-making. As board members, you will be able to apply these skills to bring about change in the community.The topics covered are:1. Types of Boards: Governance vs. Operations2. Board Responsibilities3. Committees and Working Groups4. What to Expect Once on a Board5. Mid-Point Review and Evaluation6. Leadership Primer / Communication7. Decision Making8. TeamworkAbout Focus For Ethnic WomenFocus For Ethnic Women supports women in the Waterloo Region by providing a nurturing, culturally-sensitive environment that builds self-esteem, social networks, employment-related skills, and connections to meaningful employment.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

eventName: SOLD OUT - Bloody Berlin Walking Tour
description: Join Schneider Haus staff for an evening walk through the back alleys and side streets of downtown Kitchener as we talk about some of the scary, sexy, or just plain weird characters that have called our town home. Murders, executions, grave robbing, shootouts, villainous doctors, and even pandemics of the past. Come learn a little more about Bloody Berlin….if you dare!Admission:$31 per person plus HST. Advance ticket purchase is required for this event, there will be no tickets sold at the door. Membership discount applies. No refunds.Information about Event:Suitable for ages 16 and up.Event runs rain or shine. This event takes place entirely outdoors and there will be no access to washrooms. The Historic Haus and galleries will be closed.Participants should dress for the weather and bring a flashlight (if possible).Please note: This approximately 90-minute walking tour will begin and end at Schneider Haus National Historic Site. The tour may include hills, stairs and uneven terrain.

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

eventName: SOLD OUT “The Architecture of Galt” - Soup and Stroll
description: Come for the walk, stay for the soup!What could be better on a chilly fall day, than an interesting and enlightening stroll, followed by a warm bowl of hearty and delicious Scotch Broth soup in our cozy Cottage on the banks of the Grand?Plan to join us for a fall walking tour of the area surrounding McDougall Cottage. We’ll explore the architecture of “The Granite City”, looking at how Scottish masons constructed the stone houses that the workers and business owners lived in and that the early industries of the areas were built on. We’ll talk about what happens when architectural heritage of an area is lost and how we can protect it for future generations. Finally, we’ll walk through the neighborhoods that host the baronial houses atop the hills of West Galt and then head back to the Cottage for a tasty treat.This walking tour may include hills, stairs and uneven terrain. Participants should dress for the weather. Phones are recommended, but not required, to access additional information on the sites we’ll be visiting. Note: No washroom facilities available during tour.Pre-registration is required and space is limited, so register early!

An evening of chills and thrills with two award-winning authors.Meet two award-winning authors, learn more about their latest books and stay to enjoy the refreshments, book giveaways, and more.Stop by the Rookery Books table to purchase novels and get them signed by your favourite author as a memento of this thrilling evening.The Lie Maker By Linwood BarclayIn this twisty, fast-paced thriller from the New York Times bestselling author of Find You First and Take Your Breath Away, a man desperately tries to track down his father—who was taken into witness protection years ago—before his enemies can get to him.Your dad’s not a good person. Your dad killed people, son.These are some of the last words Jack Givins’ father spoke to him before he was whisked away by witness protection, leaving Jack and his mother to pick up the shattered pieces of their lives as best they could.Years later, Jack is a grown man with problems of his own. He’s a talented but struggling author, barely scraping by on the royalties from his moderately successful first book. So when the U.S. Marshals approach him with a lucrative opportunity, he’s in no position to turn them down. They’re recruiting writers like Jack to create false histories for people in witness protection—people like Jack’s father.The coincidence is astonishing to Jack at first, but he soon realizes this may be a chance to find his dad. Only there’s one problem—Jack’s father hasn’t made contact with his handlers recently, and they have no idea where he is. He could be in serious danger, and Jack may be the only one who can find him.But how will he find a man he’s never truly known? A man who has done terrible things in his lifetime and made some deadly enemies in the process—enemies who wouldn’t think twice about using his own son against him.The Manor House By Gilly MacmillanChildhood sweethearts Nicole and Tom are a normal, loving couple—until a massive lottery win changes their lives overnight.Soon they’ve moved into a custom-built state-of-the-art Glass Barn on the stunning grounds of Lancaut Manor in Gloucestershire. They have fancy cars, expensive hobbies, and an exclusive lifestyle they never could have imagined.But this dream world quickly turns into a nightmare when Tom is found dead in the swimming pool.Nicole is devastated. Tom is her rock. And their beautiful barn —with all its smart features that never seem to work for her—is beginning to feel very lonely.Was Tom’s death a tragic accident or was it something worse? And is her life in danger as well?Limited entry without registration may be available at the door.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |
Adults |EVENT TYPE: |
Special Events |

Meet Cambridge Career Connections online for workshops on topics related to job searching and career development.All workshops are virtual, drop-in, and no registration is required. Join the program at the scheduled time on Zoom.September 19: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.September 26: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.October 3: Interview SkillsThe Interview Skills workshop offers an overview of the various elements of the entire interview process. Looking at all stages of the interview process, participants will learn the “Do’s and Don’ts” of the interview process. After attending this interactive workshop, individuals will be more confident entering an interview, know how to make a good first impression, and have the building blocks to answer interview questions appropriately.October 10: Job Searching, Networking, and Social MediaIn the interactive Job Searching and Networking workshop, participants will explore and gain knowledge about how to access the hidden vs. open job markets. Participants will explore five topics, some of which include exploring traditional vs. non-traditional job searching and the application process.Oct 17: Employer ExpectationsIn the Employer Expectations workshop, participants will explore various “Do’s and Don’ts” on how to keep a job and what employers look for and expect of their employees. From general attitude to learning about styles of manager feedback, clients will learn tips and tricks to help them meet expectations and keep their job.October 24: Getting to know your PaycheckThe interactive Getting To Know Your Paycheck workshop offers an introduction to the tax deductions that you expect to have taken off of your employment income. Looking at the breakdown of a pay stub may be confusing and stressful, especially when starting a new job. After attending this workshop, we hope that individuals have a greater understanding of what tax deductions will be taken off of employment income, why these deductions exist, and roughly how they are calculated.October 31: Workplace WellnessBe informed on how to manage workplace stress and anxiety. Not only is it important to recognize the symptoms of workplace stress, but the steps we can take to address and learn what causes it. Learn about the tips and tricks for a healthy self-care routine and how we can work to reduce/remove the source of these stressors.November 7: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.November 14: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. eventName: Trivia with a Side of Beer
description: Trivia and beer are coming to KSWRM! Jeff & Miranda’s Trivia Nights and TWB are here every Tuesday in November!Trivia and beer are coming to KSWRM! Jeff & Miranda’s Trivia Nights are at Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum every Tuesday in November! Tickets include one 16 oz. beer from Together We’re Bitter (TWB)’s selection of craft beers, plus access to museum exhibits. Delicious TWB craft beers will be available for purchase during the event. Prizes will be awarded to the highest scoring team every week AND there’s a grand prize for the highest scoring team over all 4 weeks!SAVE when you register for all 4 weeks! Select the first date (November 7) when you choose THE FULL TRIVIA EXPERIENCE.Region of Waterloo Museums Member pricing: 10% off with code- Enter the code “memcode” into the discount field and select "Apply" to get member pricing.- Please note that your membership must be valid upon booking and on the event date, or access may be denied.BYOF – Bring Your Own Food! Trivia-goers are welcome to bring their own outside food to munch on while playing!Free parking available. Do not drink and drive. This is a 19+ event. Tickets must be purchased in advance, through Eventbrite. No refunds, transfers, or exchanges.Jeff & Miranda’s Trivia Nights are run by – you guessed it – Jeff and Miranda! A fantastic and welcoming trivia team, based out of Kitchener - Waterloo, they provide awesome general and music trivia.Opened in 2016, TWB focuses on maintaining a well-rounded lineup of high quality, approachable craft beers in order to invite more people to share in what they love. A worker-owned co-operative, TWB shows how craft beer and community can support each other.

eventName: CTAL: Blinded by the Might: The Women behind Hitler
description:
Although Hitler’s inner political circle was composed entirely of men, it is difficult to understand Hitler without knowing about the women who influenced him.From childhood to death, Hitler was surrounded by women who helped him on his path to becoming dictator and warlord. We are most familiar with three of them: his mother, Klara; his niece, Geli; and his long-time girlfriend, Eva, but there were many others who played a significant role in Hitler’s life. In this talk, we will discuss the background of these women, why they fell under Hitler’s spell, how they helped further his career, and the price that they paid for being an intimate of Hitler.About Prof. Gary BruceProf. Bruce is currently developing two research projects. The first project seeks to return historical focus to the early years of the Nazi regime through an examination of violence meted out by the state, and the manner by which the German populace responded to state-sanctioned murder prior to the Holocaust. The second project deals with memory and memorialization of the Nazi era as exhibited in historic sites in and around Berlin, with a focus on the Ravensbrück memorial site. His background includes a B.A. Queen's University, M.A. University of New Brunswick, PhD McGill University, studied abroad at the University of Glasgow and the University of LeipzigAbout Cambridge Third Age Learning (CTAL)Third Age Learning (TAL) is a movement that encourages learning and discovery experiences for those in the “third age”—the stage in one’s life beyond full-time employment. Cambridge Third Age Learning is a volunteer-led committee that cultivates opportunities for discussion and engages the expertise of local university professors and community professionals, CTAL supports those who have an intellectual curiosity and an interest in life-long learning.AGE GROUP: |
Adults |EVENT TYPE: |
Lectures + Talks |TAGS: |
History |

Award-winning Canadian Military Historian, Tim Cook, will join us virtually from Ottawa.Idea Exchange is pleased to welcome back Canadian Military Historian, Tim Cook, joining us virtually from Ottawa.  Tim has thirteen successfully published books about the military history of Canada.Register to join us virtually, or register to join us in-person at the Old Post Office where we'll be screening the virtual program.Copies of the book will be available to purchase from Rookery Books at the in-person event.Canada’s Great War Fallen: Marking Their PlaceIn advance of Remembrance Day, Dr. Tim Cook, Chief Historian of the Canadian War Museum and author or editor of 17 books of Canadian military history, will offer an illustrated presentation on grief, loss, and commemoration after Canada’s Great War. When the terrible war ended on 11 November, 1918, Canadian's were confronted with marking the sacrifice of the 620,000 who served, and the 66,000 who were killed. Grappling with the meaning of the war, Canadian's built memorials across the country, created new symbols of commemoration, and forged new events like Armistice Day (later renamed Remembrance Day). Dr. Cook will use the Great War as a means to better understand the ways that Canadian's have faced mass death and loss in war, and how they continue to reflect on the Great War’s place in the country’s social memory.Registration requiredLimited entry may be available at the doorCost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

eventName: SOLD OUT - Moccasin Making Workshop with Haudenosaunee Artisan Susan Hill
description: Have you ever wondered what it takes to make moccasins? Do you want to have your own customized moccasins that you put together yourself? If so then make sure to join us for the kickoff of “Rock Your Mocs” week at a moccasin making workshop with, Haudenosaunee artisan, Susan Hill.In the space of 4 hours, using cut-to-measure pieces of buffalo and moose hide (hides will be either black, brown or tan, depending on availability) Susan will walk you through the process of piecing and sewing your moccasins together. Make a pair for yourself, or for someone you care about (what a GREAT Christmas gift these would make!).When you register, please be sure to indicate your shoe size so the moccasin components can be pre-cut to size.Reservations are required as space is limited.In order for Susan to prepare materials for the workshop, REGISTRATION CLOSES ON OCTOBER 29TH!Be sure to not miss out and reserve your spot today!
